1.text: When thou sittest to eat with a ruler, Thou considerest diligently that which is before thee,

2.text: And thou hast put a knife to thy throat, If thou art a man of appetite.

3.text: Have no desire to his dainties, seeing it is lying food.

4.text: Labour not to make wealth, From thine own understanding cease, Dost thou cause thine eyes to fly upon it? Then it is not.

5.text: For wealth maketh to itself wings, As an eagle it flieth to the heavens.

6.text: Eat not the bread of an evil eye, And have no desire to his dainties,

7.text: For as he hath thought in his soul, so is he, ‘Eat and drink,’ saith he to thee, And his heart is not with thee.

8.text: Thy morsel thou hast eaten thou dost vomit up, And hast marred thy words that are sweet.

9.text: In the ears of a fool speak not, For he treadeth on the wisdom of thy words.

10.text: Remove not a border of olden times, And into fields of the fatherless enter not,

11.text: For their Redeemer is strong, He doth plead their cause with thee.

12.text: Bring in to instruction thy heart, And thine ear to sayings of knowledge.

13.text: Withhold not from a youth chastisement, When thou smitest him with a rod he dieth not.

14.text: Thou with a rod smitest him, And his soul from Sheol thou deliverest.

15.text: My son, if thy heart hath been wise, My heart rejoiceth, even mine,

16.text: And my reins exult when thy lips speak uprightly.

17.text: Let not thy heart be envious at sinners, But—in the fear of Jehovah all the day.

18.text: For, is there a posterity? Then thy hope is not cut off.

19.text: Hear thou, my son, and be wise, And make happy in the way thy heart,

20.text: Be not thou among quaffers of wine, Among gluttonous ones of flesh,

21.text: For the quaffer and glutton become poor, And drowsiness clotheth with rags.

22.text: Hearken to thy father, who begat thee, And despise not thy mother when she hath become old.

23.text: Truth buy, and sell not, Wisdom, and instruction, and understanding,

24.text: The father of the righteous rejoiceth greatly, The begetter of the wise rejoiceth in him.

25.text: Rejoice doth thy father and thy mother, Yea, she that bare thee is joyful.

26.text: Give, my son, thy heart to me, And let thine eyes watch my ways.

27.text: For a harlot is a deep ditch, And a strange woman is a strait pit.

28.text: She also, as catching prey, lieth in wait, And the treacherous among men she increaseth.

29.text: Who hath woe? who hath sorrow? Who hath contentions? who hath plaint? Who hath wounds without cause? Who hath redness of eyes?

30.text: Those tarrying by the wine, Those going in to search out mixed wine.

31.text: See not wine when it showeth itself red, When it giveth in the cup its colour, It goeth up and down through the upright.

32.text: Its latter end—as a serpent it biteth, And as a basilisk it stingeth.

33.text: Thine eyes see strange women, And thy heart speaketh perverse things.

34.text: And thou hast been as one lying down in the heart of the sea, And as one lying down on the top of a mast.

35.text: ‘They smote me, I have not been sick, They beat me, I have not known. When I awake—I seek it yet again!’
